intro: Pseudocherleria colchica, commonly known as the Colchic Mountainflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus. It belongs to the family Primulaceae and is characterized by its delicate, bell-shaped flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils at high altitudes, showcasing its adaptability to harsh environments. Its leaves are oval and hairy, while its stems are often prostrate or creeping. Pseudocherleria colchica is noted for its ornamental value and is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
